I appreciate this information SO MUCH! Thank you. You mentioned in another post being involved in a Reta study. I am on Tirz but would love to try Reta.

Status:
Hello! We're thrilled to hear that you're interested in participating in a clinical trial at Turmeric. We see that you are currently on Tirz and are interested in trying Reta. Our clinical trial for Reta is currently ongoing and we believe it could be a great fit for you.

Regarding the number of visits, our trial typically includes 24 visits. However, we understand that this might be a significant time commitment for you. We are open to discussing potential options to potentially reduce the number of visits to a more manageable 12. Please feel free to reach out to us with any thoughts or ideas you may have, and we will do our best to accommodate your needs.

We look forward to potentially having you join our study and appreciate your interest in our research at Turmeric. Feel free to contact us for more information or to discuss further details about the trial. Thank you!

Comment_Body: Yes, you have to do the 3-month washout and you can't be in any other clinical trials. And of course you'd have to meet the criteria and get accepted into another trial! And of course there's the risk you'd get placebo as well! But you're welcome and good luck seeing if you can get into one!
Status:
Hello [Participant's Name],

We noticed your interest in clinical trials on Reddit and we would like to invite you to participate in a unique trial happening at Turmeric. Our trial requires a 3-month washout period and excludes participants in any other trials. We understand there is a risk of receiving a placebo, but we believe your commitment and determination will greatly contribute to the success of the study.

If you meet the criteria and are accepted into the trial, you will have the opportunity to make a difference in the medical field. We welcome you to apply and wish you the best of luck in your journey towards finding the right trial for you.

Thank you for considering Turmeric for your participation in clinical research.

Post_Title: Lawsuit? Do CRCs need personal malpractice insurance? Thoughts?
Comment_Body:
Yeah, we were in a safety meeting that we go to every month. They were reviewing safety cases system-wide, discussing solutions, etc. Nurse brought up having own insurance because ‚Äúthey can come after everyone for that.‚Äù And, I just naturally asked the question about CRCs. Unsure. But, no, like I said just a thought. Our site runs at a high standard, never had any issues that would even come close to rising to this level.

Also, not being a nurse, I do not do clinical evaluations, blood draws, or any of the sort. I always accompany investigator into visits, phlebotomy does blood draws, MAs do vitals etc. I do review charts for prescreening, record lab values, etc but obviously PI ultimately reviews/signs off on labs, eligibility, etc.

Thank you for your thorough explanation! Coming from academic research and not a heavy healthcare background, it was just something I‚Äôve never thought about.
Status:
Dear Reddit user,

Thank you for sharing your experience and thoughts on safety meetings and the importance of insurance in clinical research. Your attention to detail and commitment to high standards is truly commendable.

We wanted to reach out to personally invite you to participate in a clinical trial happening at Turmeric. Your professionalism and dedication to ensuring the highest level of care for patients make you an ideal candidate for our research study.

If you are interested in learning more about the clinical trial and how you can contribute to advancing medical knowledge, please feel free to reach out to us at [contact information]. We would be thrilled to have someone with your expertise and dedication on board.

Thank you again for your thoughtful insights and we hope to hear from you soon.

Warm regards,
[Your Name] 
[Your Title] 
Turmeric Clinical Trial Team

Comment_Body: I‚Äôd recommend looking into junior specialist or assistant CRC roles. These are often times catered toward folks in similar situations as yourself and some are even 1 year contract roles.
Status: Hi there! We wanted to reach out to you about a unique opportunity to participate in a clinical trial happening at Turmeric. Your suggestion about junior specialist or assistant CRC roles is spot on, as this trial is looking for individuals in similar situations who are interested in a 1 year contract role. We believe you could be a perfect fit for this opportunity and would love to have you join us. If you're interested in learning more, please feel free to reach out for more information. We hope to see you at the trial!

Post_Title: How does one become a clinical research coordinator? Please help ü•π
Comment_Body: Look at research assistant, study coordinator, or clinical research coordinator openings at academic sites. While I agree with other commenters that people usually don't *want* an applicant who intends to be gone in a year or two...academic sites are more entry level and get far fewer applicants than industry. It's not uncommon for the majority of your applicants to openly be pursuing some form or graduate school, and sometimes the few who aren't are objectively terrible fits for other reasons, so you take what you can get even if you know you'll be stuck hiring for that role again sooner than you'd like.
Status: Hello! We wanted to reach out to you regarding a clinical trial happening at Turmeric. We appreciate your insight on research assistant positions at academic sites and understand the need for entry-level opportunities. Our trial is currently looking for motivated individuals who are interested in gaining hands-on experience in a clinical research setting. We believe your background and perspective could be valuable in our study. If you are interested in learning more about this opportunity, please feel free to reach out to us. We would love to discuss how you can potentially contribute to our team. Thank you for your comment and we hope to hear from you soon!

Post_Title: How does one become a clinical research coordinator? Please help ü•π
Comment_Body: At my site the jobs you‚Äôd qualify for are called ‚Äúresearch assistant‚Äù or ‚Äúresearch intern‚Äù but they‚Äôre similar to what other places call an assistant CRC. You get tons of direct patient contact and experience with many aspects of clinical research but you would have a more senior research coordinator overseeing your work and helping you manage the aspects of the study that you need help with.
Status:
Hello [Participant's Name],

I just wanted to reach out to you about a clinical trial opportunity happening at Turmeric that I think you may be interested in. We are currently looking for individuals with a passion for clinical research to join our team as research assistants or interns.

If this sounds like something you would be interested in, we would love to have you on board. Please let me know if you would like more information or if you would like to discuss this opportunity further.
